objects.name: Most Important Things in the World Convention

details.description: Join us in a significant series of events to deliberate, contemplate, and decide what are the most important things in the world. Drinks and snacks will be served.
details.name: Most Important Things in the World Convention

details.description: I give myself the license and responsibility to depict precarious fantasies that chase idealized bodies, the picturesque landscape or garden, luxury, high fashion, and generalized narratives of history and role-play. As the emotionality of the narratives heightens to that of melodrama, my investment in the embroidery process speaks to the overwrought nature of a collapsing fantasy. The decadence of the images, in their content as well as their construction, embodies a futile yet desperately desired condition of escape.
details.name: Grad Show 2014

details.description: Brand Analysis and Scenarios based on the Engagement Level between Users and Brands
details.name: My Citi Tour

details.description: The bronze optic stamp, which exists somewhere between oddity and treasure, is used to mark blown glass to create a lens for patterned projections. Artificial light projected through the resulting glass object is transformed into a breathing organism.
details.name: Optic Stamp, 2013

details.description: In the three-minute video, Hands to Touch Molten Glass, a set of bronze hands is activated in the manner of the magician. Using both sleight of hand and lighting tricks, an ethereal visual spectacle is concocted. The technique of sleight of hand is used by magicians and alchemists to manipulate objects secretly. It uses the principles of simulation to give the impression that something has happened that has not. Bronze hands shrouded by the light of the glowing glass conjure notions of the otherworldly. Through artifact and lighting, the viewer is fused to the belief that the impossible has been made possible. For a brief moment one is joined to both the earthly and unearthly.
details.name: Hands to Touch Molten Glass, 2013

modules.text:
Hands to Touch Molten Glass, 2013
 
In the three-minute video, Hands to Touch Molten Glass, a set of bronze hands is activated in the manner of the magician. Using both sleight of hand and lighting tricks, an ethereal visual spectacle is concocted. The technique of sleight of hand is used by magicians and alchemists to manipulate objects secretly. It uses the principles of simulation to give the impression that something has happened that has not. Bronze hands shrouded by the light of the glowing glass conjure notions of the otherworldly. Through artifact and lighting, the viewer is fused to the belief that the impossible has been made possible. For a brief moment one is joined to both the earthly and unearthly.
modules.text_plain: Hands to Touch Molten Glass, 2013 In the three-minute video, Hands to Touch Molten Glass, a set of bronze hands is activated in the manner of the magician. Using both sleight of hand and lighting tricks, an ethereal visual spectacle is concocted. The technique of sleight of hand is used by magicians and alchemists to manipulate objects secretly. It uses the principles of simulation to give the impression that something has happened that has not. Bronze hands shrouded by the light of the glowing glass conjure notions of the otherworldly. Through artifact and lighting, the viewer is fused to the belief that the impossible has been made possible. For a brief moment one is joined to both the earthly and unearthly.
